title: Wednesday, 10th February, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE

This is Markets Live. Hey. Hello. Good morning.

BE

BE

And good morning from the Metro ...

11:04 am
BE

BE

And good morning from the FTSE.

BE

11:05 am
BE

There's an inevitability to these things.

BE

As soon as a "markets crash" story reaches the main book of a national newspaper, it's a buy signal.

BE

FTSE up today more than it was down yesterday. Literally billions being wiped onto pensions.

11:06 am
BE

Why? Well, that's a fair question.

BE

Perhaps we're now just being led around by Deutsche Bank.

BE

And the apparently essential systemic concern of whether some overly optimistic buyers of CoCos get converted.

11:07 am
BE

Actually, let's get Deutsche out of the way.

BE

First by reading Matt Levine yesterday, if you haven't.

BE

http://www.bloombe...es-and-libor-lying

11:08 am
BE

Who makes the argument that unlike 2008, this banking "crisis" is just a crisis for the banks, not the borrowers.

BE

Because the safety nets exist. AT1s and so forth. That's what they're for. We're currently panicking about things doing what they were designed to do.

BE

[T]oday's worries are less about hidden losses on wild bets and more about an inability to make all that much money. ... The problems are the boring and chronic problems of banks facing low growth, restructuring pains and the turn of a credit cycle; the excitement has gone out of even the crises.

11:09 am
BE

Follow that by reading Joseph.

BE

http://ftalphavill...-coco-that-popped/

BE

Whose granular understanding of this stuff is frankly terrifying.

11:10 am
BE

And finally, let's head into a chart overload from Morgan Stanley's fixed income team.

BE

Disclaimer first.

BE

Greg Case is a fixed income strategist. He is not opining on equity securities. His views are clearly delineated.

11:11 am
BE

Keep that in mind, please. Mr Case has delineated views.

BE

Clearly.

BE

To open, we get the chart that says Deutsche's cheap. Really cheap.

11:11 am
BE

BE

That's because it doesn't have enough money.

BE

11:12 am
BE

(Deutsche's over on the right.)

BE

(Also, bear in mind that the complexities and uncertainties when trying to reach a go-to capital ratio are myriad.)

BE

Finally, there's the chart showing that Deutsche is also an outlier operationally.

11:13 am
BE

Put simply, it's not very good at being a bank.

BE

BE

(Top left.)

11:13 am
BE

So here's what MOST makes of all this.

BE

On our base case DB is ~2.5% cT1 below MSe 18e go-to ratios prior to capital raising (eg announced Postbank sale). Our basecaseis for only modest capital generation over the next 2 years,as wearecautious on litigation, RWA inflation, restructuring charges,as well as coreearnings, non-core run off and thevalue of thestakes . But why have investors become more bearish? 1) Risk to revenues from rough markets. Our basecase already includes a (19)% fall in FICC/Equity trading in 2016,although could be better/worse.

BE

2) Negative rates: deflationary concerns have increased nerves on NII. At Davos one policy maker posed to me whether the lower bound was (1)%. Despite our long held concerns on negative rates, we note NIIat Danske & the Swiss banks has held up through aggressive repricing on the asset side.

11:14 am
BE

3) Legacy/credit issues.Litigation uncertainties remain high. Our base case is for a further €2.5bn in 16e & €1.4bn in 17efrom US RMBS & Russian litigation. It is also possible the litigation may not be resolved until 2017, leaving uncertainty on the stock. DB is also looking to shed €20bn legacy assets at €1-2bn cost,and has not given any update on its energy portfolio.

BE

4) Delays in divestments: On our analysis, Postbank "New" Group made a small loss in 15.The divestment has been pushed to 2017, so other capital levers may need to be pulled. DB may explore sub IPOs or sell other units).

BE

5) AT1 and technicals on CDS. As investors have become concerned on AT1 coupons, wesuspect some may have bought CDS protection as a crude hedge to illiquid AT1 positions.We notethethin CDS market could amplify impact.

11:15 am
BE

Valuation: Our new PTis mainly dueto lower assumed returns, higher CoE and greater dilution in the bear caseto reflect these prospects. DB trades at 0.4 x 2015eTNAV vs. underlying ~9% ROTE in 18e.With unresolved litigation, which the market struggles to book-end, weak capital generation & need for capital raising actions, wethink valuation is notenough to warrant an Overweight.

BE

But perhaps we in the media have hugely overjudged how interested the readership is in DB.

BE

Looking at this morning's comments, that'd be my conclusion.

11:16 am
undefined
BE

(@Underminer: right click on an image and open in new tab. I deliberately made them readable if you can do that. In terms of understandable, I can't really help.)

BE

(@theboyplunger: sorry, haven't seen Redburn on Glencore. Redburn research is a real pain in the nut to get hold of these days.)

11:18 am
BE

But enough of banks.

BE

Quick mention of Hikma before we move onto results.

BE

Not autopricing. Down 14% at pixel. £17.12

11:20 am
BE

So this is a total mess.

BE

Boehringer has tolkd Hikma that it has cut sales guidance for Roxane

BE

Which means the prospectus Hikma published on January 22 for the acquisition of Roxane is wrong.

11:21 am
BE

2016 and 2017 guidance both out, considerably..

BE

So Hikma needs to rush out a supplementary by no later than 9am on February 12, as in Friday.

BE

Ahead of a shareholder vote still scheduled for February 19, as in next Friday.

11:22 am
BE

Basically, is appears that Roxane has been increasingly reliant on selling into wholesale rather than retail.

BE

And wholesalers have been expecting bigger discounts than expected to buy its pills.

BE

Also, the cost of making and selling said pills seems to be a bit higher than previously expected.

11:22 am
BE

So. In terms of guidance ....

BE

Hikma warns to expect Roxane 2016 revenues lower than 2015, which will be around $650m

BE

Meaning the deal will be EPS dilutive in year one, not accretive as previously advertised.

11:23 am
BE

For 2017, the range on Roxane revenues moves down to $700-750m from $725-775m.

BE

Which makes it "strongly accretive" from 2017, but from a lower base.

BE

In response, Hikma's cuts its purchase price by $535m.

11:23 am
BE

Gross cash consideration of $647m vs. $1.18bn previously

BE

That's with Boehringer continuing to take a 16.71% equity stake

BE

The bump to 2016 forecasts is quite dramatic.

11:24 am
BE

Here's JP Morgan Caz.

BE

Sensitivity finds 12% EPS cut in 2016, 4% cut in 2017, modest change beyond. As a sensitivity, if we were to reflect this new information and guidance, we could see our 2016 Adj EPS cut by 12% in 2016, cut 4% in 2017, with only minor changes beyond. The changes are more minor beyond 2016 as Hikma’s view on the potential for longer-term profitability improvements, and the potential within the pipeline is unchanged, though investors may now be more cautious on this. Based on our sensitivity numbers, we previously modelled Hikma paying 12.4x 2017E EV/EBITDA, which now goes to 12.8x, though the multiple on the longer-term business may now be lower.

BE

With Hikma shares underperforming by c.13% this morning, we believe the negative share-price reaction is an over-reaction vs. the magnitude of the likely longer-term downgrades, though we appreciate that this morning’s new disclosure does raise issues on credibility around Roxane, and decreases confidence in the transaction’s accretion profile, which to some extent does rely on belief in management comments, due to
limited disclosure on what is in the Roxane pipeline. Based on our first read of the release, we believe today’s sell-off could be a good buying opportunity on a 12 month view, with the new disclosure implying low initial accretion, but not changing the long-term strategic rationale, nor long-term accretion profile of the deal, which is about buying a pipeline.

11:26 am
BE

Goldman also saying you shouldn't over-react.

BE

We estimate that the updated outlook implies downside risk of US$25-50 mn
pa to 2016/17 company-compiled consensus for Roxane, which accounts
for only 1-2% of Hikma’s total revenues. There are no details on the impact
of the higher cost of sales on profitability in 2015; however, Hikma
reiterated its previous target to achieve a 35% EBITDA margin for Roxane
in the medium term. At the same time, the lower purchasing price should
positively affect Hikma’s leverage position and suggests lower interest
expenses compared with current consensus expectations.

BE

Do we really need an analyst to tell us that paying less for something will lower interest expenses? Perhaps we do.

11:26 am
BE

The news will likely be negatively received given that new details about
Roxane are still emerging after several months of due diligence; however,
we believe the reduction of US$0.5 bn to the deal price more than offsets
the negative impact from lower revenue expected in 2016-17 (which has no
impact on the pipeline, the key driver of this acquisition).

undefined
BE

Elsewhere among the fallers, Arm requested.

11:28 am
BE

Ah bloody hell. Autopricing's borked. Arm down 2% at 921 at pixel.

BE

And the problem is "broadly"

BE

Increased economic uncertainty may influence consumer and enterprise spending, potentially impacting semiconductor revenues and industry confidence. Based on current conditions in the semiconductor market, we expect Group dollar revenues for the full year to be broadly in line with market expectations.

11:04 am
BE

Good morning from the Telegraph ...

BE

It's a euphemism used by companies that want the top end of the range to move towards the bottom end of the range.

BE

So, while there's nothing particularly bad in the Arm numbers, the unusually cautious guidance is the damper.

11:31 am
BE

Francois Meunier at Morgan Stanley's very good. Here's what he made of it all.

BE

Revenues ahead of consensus at $408m vs $403m. Royalties ex catch up
revenues grew 24% yoy, a deceleration vs the 37% printed in Q3 but a tad
lower than the October consensus of 30%. ARM outperformed the industry by
27% in Q4.
In terms of pricing - we believe that ARM continues on its upward trajectory
with ASP per chip of 4.7c up from 4.3c last year. Seasonally Q4 can be weaker
due to more shipments of legacy technology chips. This quarter shipments of
v8 grew 33% yoy to 240m units. Mali shipments were up 36% yoy.

BE

Licensing revenues were flat yoy but the backlog has increased 10% qoq. We
should highlight the new Qualcomm licence which is called "built on ARM
cortex technology" and might relate either to servers or to customised chips
for smartphones. Qualcomm (covered by James Faucette) hosts its analysts
day tomorrow evening UK time and we might hear more details about this.
Licensing backlog was strong because of new technologies and thus it
reinforces the view that it is a good time for ARM to invest in more opex for
the future.
Costs were higher than expected; 50% due to the rapid move in FX and 50%
due to quicker hiring of new joiners. That said, PBT was £139m still ahead of
consensus £137m and EPS was in-line at 8.2p.

11:32 am
BE

Management did not warn on 2016, a relief in this market - "we expect group
dollar revenues to be broadly in line with market expectations". Broadly is a
new adjective but we believe in the current macro environment there is no
need for management to be heroic. ARMv8 was 50% of smartphone
shipments so still has room to grow and lift pricing upwards.

BE

Meanwhile, at Credit Suisse .....

BE

Extrapolating results, we believe that
consensus numbers are unlikely to see any material revisions. However, we also
note that given increased economic uncertainty along with recent weakness in
the Apple and Samsung supply chain, there remains a potential risk that
consensus may head towards CS revenue estimates as we go through 2016.

11:33 am
BE

And Barclays.

BE

Given consensus is priced at GBPUSD1.55, we see a 2-3% tailwind to GBP revenue forecasts based on the company’s sanctioning of USD forecasts. While we had hoped for more in terms of returns, the ARM model is intact of outperforming the underlying market, driving operating leverage while investing in the business and thereby growing EPS and cash flow at 20%+ rates. ARM shares trade on 22x/18x 2017/18e PE, very attractive multiples for a company driving mid-20% EPS growth.

BE

(@RuminationsOn: but it has results! And it was requested!)

11:34 am
undefined
BE

RAW, you say? Well, okay.

BE

First, I should probably just flag up this Vertex Pharmaceuticals theory in the paper overnight.

11:36 am
BE

US maker of cystic fibrosis drugs. Reinvented itself after its Hepatitis treatment was overtaken by someone else's Hepatitis treatment, I think.

BE

It's had an appalling year to date. Down more than 30%.

BE

Basically, its first drug post reinvention did fantastically well in the launch quarter, then not so well afterwards.

11:37 am
BE

Consensus cranked up, then cranked back down again.

BE

Anyway, there's an idea around that it might be open to approaches. And that AstraZeneca's open to the possibility of making one.

BE

It'd be a big deal, given Vertex has a $20bn cap even after its slump. But it kinda makes sense given the potential blockbuster value of its approved drugs.

11:40 am
BE

Anyway, I believe this talk all stems from the big JP Morgan healthcare conference last month.

BE

Don't know if there's anything progressing since then, but if there is I'm sure the companies would tell us.

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 3,922, up 7.75 (+0.20%), High: 3,986, Low: 3,919, Volume: 1.42m
11:41 am
BE

@TheLeggie: making note of all those caveats and the obvious early stage-ness here, I'd say around bandit3 or bandit4 .)

BE

Elsewhere among RAW .......

BE

Smart people still seem to be buying Regus.

11:42 am
Regus plc (RGU:LSE): Last: 269.70, up 5.7 (+2.16%), High: 274.50, Low: 263.90, Volume: 455.27k
BE

No idea what the story is there, and its CEO still holds a controlling stake.

BE

But I note it in passing.

11:43 am
BE

And RAW #3 ........

BE

.... especially for the US retail punters who like to email me threats and suchlike.

BE

You'll remember this Xenoport story back in November. http://ftalphavill...rgeted-by-us-peer/

11:44 am
BE

Saying Supernus was weighing up an offer.

BE

Reuters followed it in late January saying the company had put itself up for sale. http://mobile.reut...icle/idUSKCN0UZ2SZ

BE

So, the way I've heard it, the initial leak screwed up the talks with Supernus .....

11:47 am
BE

...... But even after that setback, the sale process referred to by Reuters continues in a more formal manner.

BE

Supernus still involved, but also some rather bigger names such as Biogen, Cellgen and Amgen.

BE

All RAW info. Don't invest money on market rumours that you can't afford to lose.

11:48 am
BE

And try not to send me threatening emails. Thanks.

undefined
BE

Okay, what else?

11:50 am
BE

Tullow! Certainly.

Tullow Oil PLC (TLW:LSE): Last: 144.30, down 17.2 (-10.65%), High: 163.20, Low: 144.20, Volume: 7.03m
BE

The results are basically in line with where we'd been guided.

11:52 am
BE

The problem with Tullow remains its debt, and the perilous risk that someone will drop a spanner down a pipe

BE

Which'd push back a project by X months and it'd breach covenants.

BE

That risk remains, and today's numbers doesn't really do much to move the argument either way.

11:53 am
BE

Jefferies says ..........

BE

Tullow Oil's FY15 results are in line operationally with a positive guidance (to
us) on the ability to reduce capex to $300m from 2017 if conditions require it.
However, a stark reminder of liquidity risk & covenant reality is contained in
the going concern statement which renews focus to the company stated goal
of "the primary focus of the Group in 2016 remains to deleverage the balance sheet"

BE

Net loss of US$1.0bn inline with consensus. The loss includes US$1.1bn pre-tax writedowns/
impairments which is in line with guidance from Jan trading update. Cashflow from
ops of US$1bn in 2015 (with $365m support from hedges). YE15a net debt of US$4.0bn
was as guided. last year's guided cost savings of US$500m over 3 yrs are "on track" and the dividend remains suspended.

11:53 am
BE

2016 capex US$1.1bn but lower for longer world can be ~US$300m p.a. 2016
capex was lowered from US$1.2bn at the last trading statement with the main components
being US$600m TEN devex & US$150m Jubilee devex. In addition to capex there is an
"onerous rig contract charge of $0.2bn" which is a cash cost outside capex in 2016 for a
stacked drilling rig. 2015 capex of US$1.7bn was as guided but we note the (positive)
comment that TLW believe it can "reduce capex to around $300m for 2017 onwards if market
conditions do not improve". This is much lower than the "production support" capex of
around $500m p.a. we assume (from discussions with the company).

BE

Production to grow into 2016 (TEN on-stream). 2016 guidance of 78-87kboe/d (vs.
JEFe: 78.8kboe/d) compares to 73.4kboe/d in 2015 with growth coming from first oil from
the TEN development offshore Ghana (47.2% WI), "on schedule for between July and August
2016". JEFe is at the lower-end of the range as we are more cautious on the ramp up of TEN production during 2015 but overall we still have the company reaching 96.5kboe/d in 2017 and greater than 100kboe/d from 2018, generally in-line with TLW's expectation of "producing around 100,000b/d in West Africa in 2017".

BE

Net debt of US$4.0bn at YE15 we see growing to US$4.8bn. The FY15 net debt
is as guided and TLW disclose 4.1x EBITDAX at YE15. Using a US$43/b average oil price
for 2016 we project a YE16e net debt of US$4.8bn at 6x EBITDAX. Tullow is in discussions
with banks regarding its March debt redetermination and highlights extension of the $1bn
Revolving Credit facility maturing in April 2017 (undrawn) and $3.7bn Reserves Based
Lending facility which starts to amortise in Oct 2016 ($3.0bn drawn). We note the going
concern comment on liquidity risk that "the volatility of the oil price...[means that]...Group
may become technically non-compliant with on of its financial covenants at the end of 2016".
We expect the call to focus on debt redetermination expectations.

11:54 am
BE

2P reserves down to 321mmboe (simply due to production) and implying a trading
metric of US$20.0/boe, still a healthy premium to peers such as Lundin Petroleum at US
$11/boe. TLW 2C resources of 975mmboe (65% in Uganda & Kenya) are actually up from
67mmboe y/y due to +ve revisions in East Africa.
Kenya Resource comment, still 600mmb. Kenya 2C gross resources are unchanged
from 600mmb but the upside potential to ~1bnboe is still flagged due to the Etom-2 result
& surrounding prospectivity at the northern end of the South Lokichar Basin. Realisable
East Africa value (Uganda and Kenya) is becoming ever more of a question as the oil price
weakens and balance sheet versus equity valuations come to the fore.
Summary. Operational news inline (+ve on capex projections) & 2016 hedging covers 52%
of entitlement oil production at ~US$75/b. However, deleverage/East Africa monetisation
remains the focus.

BE

Now down 10% live. Genuinely struggling to understand that.

BE

Down 10% because a tax credit was a bit lower than expected?

11:56 am
BE

Because the numbers were pre-announced and the balance sheet is what it is. There was no news news there apart from a refinancing schedule.

BE

Ah, I dunno. It's not my job to understand the market.

undefined
11:59 am
BE

On Glencore, sorry. My requests for Redburn have once again been ignored by people scared of being kicked off their distro list. Expect more of this kind of thing as Mifid II kicks in.

BE

We'll be left with Redburn and Bernstein putting out research, which we're not allowed to read, and a few dozen market communications saying "buy our clients".

BE

("How is that different from now?" you could ask, and you might have a point.)

12:00 pm
BE

Anyway, there is a Glencore downgrade from SocGen that I can share.

BE

Update The mining sector has rebounded dramatically of late on the back of an FX-led
rebound in commodity prices, with the FTSE all-share mining index erasing losses posted
in early January. Such a performance is all the more remarkable given the pain suffered by
the broader market amidst concerns over slowing global growth. At this juncture, we do not
see the right combination of fundamentals to sustain the positive momentum in mining
names. We thus leave our target price for Glencore unchanged ahead of full-year financial
results. As a result, we cut our rating from Buy to Hold, with fundamentals finely balanced
and 12m projected TSR having narrowed to 6%.

BE

Production results preview Q4 production results are due Thursday, 11 February. We
expect a significant qoq decline in the Copper and Zinc units, reflecting cash-preservation
measures implemented during the quarter. Full-year production is likely to come close to
the lower bound of management guidance for all base metals, with 1,450kt for copper and
1,420kt for zinc. We think the ferrochrome production picked up qoq, bringing the annual
tally to c.1.45mt est., while coal output declined slightly, bringing the total for the year to
135-136mt est.. The results are unlikely to be share price-moving given the market’s
current focus on profit margins rather than tonnes mined.

12:01 pm
BE

How we value the stock Our target price is based on a scenario analysis (55% base
case, 45% bear case) using a combination of NPV-based estimates (inputting 8.0% real
WACC, zero long-term growth) and target P/E multiples (11x 2016e EPS for marketing, 10x
2020e EPS for industrial operations). See page 2 for details.
Events, catalysts & risks to price target, rating & recommendation Risks: adverse
changes to the global macro/commodity price situation (10% change in copper/thermal
coal price leads to a c.8% change in 2016e EBITDA, all else being equal) and/or further
significant US dollar strengthening (10% appreciation equals a c.10% decline in EBITDA);
deterioration in marketing segment profitability/turnover (we forecast $2.5bn in EBIT in
2016); failure to complete the planned asset disposals/low valuations achieved (we expect
c.$2.5bn from asset sales in 2016); negative developments in the corporate bond market.

BE

You'll remember the Sunday Times story with regards to Glencore's pending streaming deal, with the curiously low price tag.

BE

Post its rescue rights issue, the Glencore machine became quite good at news management. Perhaps that was news management. I guess we'll find out.

12:03 pm
undefined
BE

@Soundbuy, we only hear sporadically from Murph while he's doing his Heart of Darkness thing.

BE

Here's last night's update.

12:04 pm
BE

Amazing to see the way QE has fed through into a place like Maputo. It’s mad. Everyone has a car. The roads are gridlocked and all the pavements are full of parked cars — everywhere you look.
All on consumer finance.
It’s been a while since i was in Maputo proper. Transformation is amazing (and terrifying).

BE

But that'll do for today, let's push off.

BE

I'll be spending lunch reading this:

12:06 pm
BE

BE

http://www.finextr...x?newsitemid=28451

BE

"City grandee Rich Ricci ....."

12:07 pm
BE

Cripes.

BE

Thanks for joining. Thanks for the reminder to turn the comments off.

BE

Enjoy Yellen, or not. And we'll see you on the other side.

11:29 am
BE

"broadly in line" isn't in line.
